did.unittitle: Union League of Philadelphia Activities/Guest Committee records

bioghist.p: The Union League of Philadelphia was founded in 1862 as a patriotic society to support the policies of President Abraham Lincoln. It evolved to its current identity as a non-sectarian and non-partisan private club. The Guest Committee was one of the original committees listed in the 1872 annual report. Over time, the Guest and House Committees were responsible for arranging programs. In 1979 the Guest Committee formed an Entertainment sub-committee, and in 1984 the Guest Committee was renamed Activities Committee.

scopecontent.p: The series has been arranged into six subseries: Affinity/Recreation, Armed Services, Entertainment, Junior Committee, Ladies Luncheon, and Public Affairs/Guest Speakers. The subseries within the Activities series are based on 1998 subcommittee assignments. Most of the subseries contain chronological files related to a particular group's activities. The files in most of the subseries consist primarily of printed materials for events, such as announcements, invitations, programs, and tickets. Some files include minutes, correspondence, clippings, member directories, newsletters, or menus. Within the Public Affairs/Guest Speakers subseries, many of the items are autographed by the speakers. There are some printed addresses for Lincoln Day festivities. Files related to Union League anniversaries and events surrounding the U.S. Bicentennial include committee correspondence and printed materials. The Ladies Luncheon Committee contains financial information including bank statements, canceled checks and invoices.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
